questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents with a 2-day history of left leg pain. His temperature is 38.7°C (103°F). He has a harsh systolic murmur and echocardiographic evidence of bacterial endocarditis. If this patient has developed hematogenous osteomyelitis, his bone infection would most likely be found in which of the following anatomic locations?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The metaphysis of long bones is the most common site for hematogenous osteomyelitis, especially in children and adults with predisposing conditions such as endocarditis.

  • The metaphyseal region contains slow-flowing, sinusoidal capillaries within loops that favour bacterial seeding.
  • Bacteria proliferate, induce inflammation and cause vascular thrombosis → leading to necrosis and abscess formation.
  • In children, infection may reach the periosteum easily due to loosely attached periosteum → forming draining sinuses.
  • Involucrum (new bone formation around the necrotic focus) may develop in chronic cases.

Explanation of Other Options:

Body of a flat bone (Option A): Rarely involved; flat bones do not have the vascular architecture that favours hematogenous seeding.

Diaphysis of a long bone (Option B): Less susceptible due to different blood supply and higher bone density.

Epiphysis of a long bone (Option C): The epiphyseal plate in children separates metaphyseal vessels from epiphyseal vessels, making infection here uncommon.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female on corticosteroids for a long duration presented with pain in the right hip region initially associated with activity, and later became constant. A fracture at the neck, along with irregular densities of the cancellous bone of the femur, is noticed on X-ray. The head of the femur is replaced by an artificial head. The histopathological examination of the head shows empty lacunae and necrotic adipocytes. What is the probable diagnosis based on histology?
questions.solution:
Avascular necrosis (osteonecrosis) is characterised by bone and marrow infarction. Corticosteroid therapy is a major risk factor. Histologically, it shows:

  • Empty lacunae: Indicative of osteocyte death in trabeculae
  • Necrotic adipocytes: Result from marrow infarction
  • Fatty acids bind calcium → forming insoluble soaps
  • Trabeculae serve as scaffolding for new bone deposition

Explanation of Other Options:

Osteomyelitis (Option A): Shows inflammatory infiltrate and bacterial colonies; not empty lacunae with fat necrosis.

Paget's disease (Option C): Histology shows a mosaic pattern of lamellar bone with cement lines.

Osteogenesis imperfecta (Option D): A genetic disorder with defective type I collagen; presents with thin cortex, not necrosis.

choices.text: Tumour cells forming unmineralized osteoid or mineralised bone

questions.text: A 51-year-old man presents with bone pain around his knee that he has had for a long time. Radiologic studies reveal a lytic lesion of the distal end arising in the metaphysis that elevates the periosteum. The resected lesion was sent for histopathological examination, and a diagnosis of osteosarcoma was made and the image is shown below. Based on which characteristic features diagnosis of osteosarcoma was made.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Diagnosis of osteosarcoma is based on the production of malignant osteoid or bone by tumour cells, which is the key diagnostic feature.

  • Osteosarcomas demonstrate:
    • Pleomorphism with large hyperchromatic nuclei
    • Bizarre tumour giant cells
    • Abundant abnormal mitotic figures
    • Tumour necrosis and vascular invasion
  • Extensive necrosis and intravascular invasion are also common.
  • Diagnosis of osteosarcoma requires the presence of malignant tumour cells producing unmineralized osteoid or mineralised bone, which is typically fine and lacelike, but can also form broad sheets or primitive trabeculae.
  • The image shows lace-like eosinophilic osteoid deposition surrounded by malignant cells, diagnostic of osteosarcoma.

Explanation of Other Options:

Pleomorphism with mitosis (Option A): Present but not specific; diagnostic confirmation requires malignant osteoid.

Cartilage differentiation (Option B): Suggests chondrosarcoma.

Necrosis with tumour giant cells (Option C): Seen in many malignancies; not diagnostic.

questions.text: A 49-year-old female presented with pain in the shoulder, which is progressive in nature, associated with shoulder activity. X-rays confirm a mass lesion in the scapula, and excision of the lesion is done. Gross examination revealed a glistening lesion. Histopathological examination revealed as shown in the image below. Based on the above findings, what is your probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The image shows lobules of hyaline cartilage with increased cellularity and moderate cytologic atypia infiltrating the surrounding bone - hallmark features of chondrosarcoma.

  • Chondrosarcomas are malignant cartilage-producing tumours that show infiltrative growth into marrow spaces.
  • They exhibit increased cellularity, cytologic atypia, and sometimes binucleated chondrocytes.
  • Grossly, the tumours are gray-white, glistening, translucent or gelatinous.
  • The diagnosis is made based on cartilage matrix production by malignant cells with an infiltrative pattern and atypical chondrocytes.

Explanation of Other Options:

Osteosarcoma (Option A): Malignant osteoid-forming tumour; histology shows lace-like osteoid deposition, pleomorphic cells, and mitoses, not seen in this image.

Giant cell tumour (Option C): Composed of mononuclear stromal cells and uniformly distributed osteoclast-type giant cells; lacks cartilage matrix.

Osteochondroma (Option D): Benign cartilage-capped bony outgrowth with continuity of cortex and medulla, no malignant features or marrow infiltration.

questions.text: A 22-year-old female presented with swelling and pain in the left knee joint for 4 months. Pain is progressively increasing in intensity. X-ray revealed the origin of the mass from the proximal tibia with destruction of the cortex. Curettage was done, and the histopathological image of the lesion is shown below. Based on the above findings, what is your probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The image shows numerous multinucleated osteoclast-type giant cells scattered in a background of mononuclear stromal cells, which is characteristic of Giant Cell Tumour (Osteoclastoma).

  • Commonly occurs at the epiphysis of long bones (e.g., distal femur, proximal tibia).
  • May extend into the metaphysis.
  • Causes cortical destruction with the formation of a bulging soft tissue mass.
  • Histology: Uniform mononuclear stromal cells and osteoclast-type giant cells with numerous nuclei (>100).
  • Mitotic activity and necrosis may be present, but bone or cartilage formation is absent.

Explanation of Other Options:

Osteosarcoma (Option A): Shows malignant osteoid formation by pleomorphic cells; not seen here.

Chondrosarcoma (Option B): Composed of malignant cartilage-producing cells; would show lobulated cartilage matrix.

Ewing's sarcoma (Option D): Composed of uniform small round blue cells with scant cytoplasm; no giant cells.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy presents with a swelling on his left tibia. An X-ray of the leg shows a destructive process, with indistinct borders and an "onion-skin" pattern of periosteal bone. Histologic examination reveals uniform, small, round, dark blue nuclei (shown in the image). Immunohistochemistry for CD 99 is positive and LCA negative. Which of the following is the most likely tumour?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical-radiological features and histology are classic for Ewing's sarcoma, a small round blue cell tumour.

Explanation of Other Options:

Osteosarcoma (Option A): Malignant bone tumour that produces osteoid; histology shows malignant osteoblasts and lace-like osteoid, not small round cells.

Ameloblastoma (Option C): Odontogenic tumour of the jaw, unrelated to long bones, and has distinctive epithelial histology.

Giant cell tumour (Option D): Composed of multinucleated osteoclast-type giant cells and mononuclear stromal cells, not small blue round cells.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman has been bothered by a bump on the dorsum of her left wrist for the past 4 months. On physical examination, there is a 1 cm firm but fluctuant subcutaneous nodule over an extensor tendon of the left wrist. The nodule is painful on palpation and movement. Mucoid fluid is aspirated from the nodule. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The lesion is small, fluctuant, over a tendon sheath, and aspirates mucoid fluid - classic features of a ganglion cyst.

  • A ganglion cyst has a thin wall and clear, mucoid content.
  • It arises in the connective tissue of a joint capsule or tendon sheath.
  • The extensor surfaces of the hands and feet are the most common sites, particularly the wrist.
  • Ganglion cysts probably arise after trauma from focal myxoid degeneration of connective tissue to produce a cystic space.
  • They may regress. If not, and if they are painful, they can be excised.

Explanation of Other Options:

Giant cell tumour (Option B): Typically occurs in the epiphysis of long bones in younger adults; composed of mononuclear stromal cells and multinucleated osteoclast-type giant cells; not cystic.

Lipoma (Option C): Benign tumour of adipose tissue; presents as a soft, mobile mass, not fluctuant and does not yield mucoid fluid.

Nodular fasciitis (Option D): Rapidly growing reactive fibroblastic proliferation; appears as a solid mass in upper extremities; lacks cystic content and is usually not fluctuant.

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman has had increasing pain and deformities in her hands and feet for the past 10 years. On physical examination, the joint shows swelling, erythema, and tenderness. Synovium biopsy is taken to reach at a diagnosis. Microscopic examination shows lymphoid follicles as shown below. What is your probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The histology shows dense lymphocytic infiltrate forming lymphoid follicles, which is characteristic of rheumatoid arthritis (RA). The features include:

  1. Synovial cell hyperplasia and villous hypertrophy
  2. Dense inflammatory infiltrate with lymphoid follicle formation: Comprising CD4+ T cells, B cells, plasma cells, dendritic cells, and macrophages
  3. Increased vascularity due to angiogenesis
  4. Fibrinopurulent exudate on synovial surfaces
  5. Osteoclastic bone erosion and pannus formation: Leading to cartilage and bone destruction

Explanation of Other Options:

Tuberculosis (Option A): Shows caseating granulomas with Langhans giant cells, not lymphoid follicle formation.

Osteoarthritis (Option B): Lacks inflammatory infiltrates; shows cartilage degeneration and subchondral cysts instead.

Suppurative arthritis (Option D): Characterised by abundant neutrophils, necrosis, and pus; lymphoid follicles are absent.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presented painful enlarging mass in the wrist associated with tenderness. After CT, amputation was done; the cut section of the femur is shown along with the corresponding histopathological image. Identify the type of tumour.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The histological image shows numerous multinucleated osteoclast-type giant cells distributed uniformly within a background of mononuclear stromal cells - a classic feature of osteoclastoma (giant cell tumour of bone).

Explanation of Other Options:

Osteosarcoma (Option A): Malignant tumour producing osteoid; histology shows pleomorphic spindle cells with lace-like osteoid, not seen here.

Aneurysmal bone cyst (Option B): Shows blood-filled spaces with fibrous septa, osteoclast-like giant cells, and reactive bone; lacks uniform stromal background.

Paget's disease (Option D): Features a mosaic pattern of lamellar bone; no prominent giant cells or mononuclear stromal cells.

questions.text: Histology from a bone biopsy from the proximal femur is given below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given image demonstrates a classic mosaic pattern of lamellar bone, a hallmark feature of Paget's disease. The irregular, jigsaw puzzle-like cement lines and disorganised architecture reflect the sclerotic phase of the disease.

Explanation of Other Options:

Osteomalacia (Option A): Shows unmineralized osteoid and widened osteoid seams, not the cement line mosaic seen here.

Osteoporosis (Option C): Demonstrates thinning of trabeculae and reduced bone mass without architectural disorganisation.

Osteosclerosis (Option D): Shows diffuse increased bone density, but lacks the mosaic cement line pattern unique to Paget disease.

questions.text: X-ray shows a lytic lesion in the calcaneus in a young adult. Biopsy shows the following diagnosis:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The histopathology shows characteristic features of tenosynovial giant cell tumour, previously known as pigmented villonodular synovitis, including:

  • Hyperplasia of synovium and tendon sheaths
  • Presence of scattered multinucleated giant cells
  • Hemosiderin-laden macrophages (brown pigment within macrophages)
  • Mixed inflammatory infiltrate and fibrous stroma

These findings are diagnostic of pigmented villonodular synovitis, most often presenting as a diffuse or localised tumour in young to middle-aged adults, often involving the ankle or knee joint.

Explanation of Other Options:

Ochronosis (Option B): Characterised by deposition of homogentisic acid pigment in connective tissues (e.g. cartilage, not synovium). No hemosiderin-laden macrophages or multinucleated giant cells.

Osteomyelitis (Option C): Shows necrotic bone, neutrophilic infiltration, and bacterial colonies, not seen here.

Eumycetoma (Option D): A chronic granulomatous fungal infection with granules and abscesses; not relevant to synovial tissue.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male came with complaints of swelling around the knee joint. Histopathological examination of the swelling demonstrated many giant cells interspersed with mononuclear cells. Your most probable diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Giant cell tumour is characterised by numerous osteoclast-type multinucleated giant cells uniformly interspersed with mononuclear stromal cells, arising typically in the epiphysis of long bones.


Anatomic locations of common primary bone and cartilage tumors.

Explanation of Other Options:

Osteosarcoma (Option A): Malignant bone-forming tumour with pleomorphic cells and osteoid production.

Chondrosarcoma (Option B): Malignant cartilage-producing tumour showing lobules of hyaline cartilage.

Ewing's sarcoma (Option C): Small round blue cell tumour seen in diaphysis; lacks giant cells.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female presented with swelling around the knee joint. Biopsy showed giant cells interspersed with mononuclear cells. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Giant cell tumour of bone is characterised by the presence of numerous osteoclast-type multinucleated giant cells uniformly distributed among mononuclear stromal cells, as seen in the provided histopathology image.

  • Giant cell tumours often destroy the overlying cortex, resulting in a bulging soft tissue mass delineated by a thin shell of reactive bone.
  • Grossly, the tumours are large, red-brown masses that frequently undergo cystic degeneration.
  • Histologically, the tumours consist of uniform oval mononuclear tumour cells and abundant osteoclast-type giant cells with 100 or more nuclei.
  • Necrosis and mitotic activity may be prominent.
  • Although reactive bone may be present, especially at the periphery, tumour cells do not synthesise bone or cartilage.

Explanation of Other Options:

Rheumatoid arthritis (Option A): Inflammatory arthritis; histology shows pannus formation and chronic inflammation, not giant cell-rich tumour.

Osteosarcoma (Option B): Malignant bone-forming tumour with pleomorphic cells producing osteoid.

Aneurysmal bone cyst (Option C): Contains blood-filled cystic spaces and scattered osteoclast-like giant cells, not uniformly interspersed as in GCT.

questions.text: Rheumatoid arthritis is associated with all except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Neutrophils are increased in the synovial fluid of Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA), especially during acute inflammation. Hence, “Decreased neutrophils” is incorrect.

Key inflammatory cells in RA based on histology:

  • CD4+ T cells (Th1 and Th17), macrophages, plasma cells, dendritic cells, and neutrophils are prominently involved in the synovium.
  • Pannus formation involves fibroblasts, inflammatory cells (including macrophages, lymphocytes), and causes cartilage and bone erosion.
  • Neutrophils predominate in the synovial fluid, while lymphocytes and macrophages dominate the synovial membrane.

(Other options ruled out)
